heading: An Early Advocate for Web Apps
content:
The full Safari engine is inside of iPhone. And so, you can write amazing [web] apps that look exactly and behave exactly like apps on the iPhone. And these apps can integrate perfectly with iPhone services. They can make a call, they can send an email, they can look up a location on Google Maps.

Steve Jobs
2007 Apple Worldwide Developer Conference

heading: iPhone Apps Timeline: 2007
content:
• The iPhone is introduced
  • All native apps developed by Apple
  • All third-party apps must be web apps

heading: iPhone Apps Timeline: 2008
content:
• Apple releases a software development kit for third parties to build native iPhone apps
  • The App Store goes live
  • Native apps take over the world

heading: Why Isn't There a Web App For That?
Native Apps: The Good
content:
• Better access to device features
  • Higher perceived performance
  • Offline functionality
  • Re-engageable (updates and alerts via notifications)
  • App stores provide discoverability

heading: Native Apps: The Bad
content:
• Apps must be downloaded and installed from an app store
  • Multiple platforms mean heavy development costs
  • Complicated and slow app store approval process

heading: Web Apps: The Good
content:
• Universal, can run on any browser or device
  • Build for one platform (the web)
  • No lengthy download/install
  • No app store approval process

heading: Web Apps: The Bad
content:
• Limited access to native device features (historically)
  • Slow performance over poor connections, no offline access
  • Must support many devices and browsers
  • No app store, so discoverability is reduced
  • Limited re-engageability

heading: What the Devil is a PWA?
content:
• A buzzword
  • A website
  • A set of principles that make a website reliable, fast, and engaging
  • A spectrum of web technologies that shrink the gap between a web app and a native app
  • The best parts of native apps and web apps, smooshed together

heading: Standard Traits
content:
• Secure
  • Responsive
  • Progressive
  • Evergreen
  • Linkable

heading: Secure
content:
• Website is served over a secure, encrypted connection (SSL)
  • Basic requirement for PWA other technologies to function

heading: Responsive
content:
• Website layout, content and features adapt to any screen size and device
  • Mobile-friendly and touch-friendly

heading: Progressive
content:
• Website functions on any browser and device
  • Enhanced features and functionality are activated for more-capable browsers and devices

heading: Evergreen
content:
• Users always have the latest version of the website
  • Website updates itself automatically when a network connection is present

heading: Linkable
content:
• Easily share the app via a URL
  • Bypass app store
  • Deep-linking to interior pages
  • URL should indicate the current state of the application, allowing it to be retained/reloaded

heading: Emerging Traits
content:
• Feels like an app
  • Installable
  • Connectivity-independent
  • Discoverable
  • Re-engageable

heading: Feels Like an App
content:
• Frameless, full-screen browser experience
  • App shell that loads quickly and can be cached
  • Functionality is separated from content
  • Smooth page transitions, minimal page refreshes

heading: Installable
content:
• Users can easily install a shortcut to the website on their home screen
  • Developers have control over how their website appears and how it can be launched
    • Display name and icon of the installed shortcut
    • Orientation (portrait, landscape)
    • Full-screen, no browser chrome

heading: Connectivity-independent
content:
• Website should work on low-quality networks or offline
  • Control what is shown to users when no connectivity
  • Cache-first networking
  • Content is separated from the app frame, can be refreshed when connectivity improves

heading: Discoverable
content:
• Websites identify themselves to search engines as an application that can be cataloged and ranked
  • App directories are emerging
  • PWAs are appearing alongside native apps in some app stores

heading: Re-engageable
content:
• Website should be able to re-engage with the user, even when it is not currently in use
  • The new Push Notifications API allows a website to send notifications to a user’s device

heading: How PWAs Improve Upon Traditional Web Apps
Web Apps: The Bad
content:
• Limited access to native device features (historically)
  • Slow performance over poor connections, no offline access
  • Must support many devices and browsers
  • No app store, so discoverability is reduced
  • Limited re-engageability

heading: PWAs: The Good
content:
• Limited access to native device features (historically) Ever-improving access to native device features thanks to new and emerging web technologies
  • Slow performance over poor connections, no offline access Loads quickly on poor connections and has partial functionality offline
  • Must support many devices and browsers Progressive enhancement ensures a minimum functional experience across devices and browsers
  • No app store, so discoverability is reduced App directories are emerging and app stores are beginning to feature PWAs
  • Limited re-engageability Notifications can be pushed to the user, even when PWA not currently in use

heading: How PWAs Improve Upon Native Apps
Native Apps: The Bad
content:
• Apps must be downloaded and installed from an app store
  • Multiple platforms mean heavy development costs
  • Complicated and slow app store approval process

heading: PWAs: The Good
content:
• Apps must be downloaded and installed from an app store PWAs are websites. They are linkable, shareable and can download and launch quickly
  • Multiple platforms mean heavy development costs PWAs are websites. They are built with standard web technologies and can run on any web browser
  • Complicated and slow app store approval process PWAs are websites. There is no approval process beyond adhering to the tenets of PWAs

content:

  • Find an Advisor search functionality
  • Blog, updated weekly
  • Real-time investment fund information

heading: Challenges Within Our Control
content:
• Complicated, new technologies
    • Development team training required
    • Increased development effort
  • Increased QA effort and new QA tools
  • Selling benefits of PWAs to clients

heading: Challenges Outside of Our Control
content:
• Varied browser and OS support
    • Android/Chrome: Already well supported
    • iOS/Safari: Supported(?) in 11.3 release
    • Windows/Edge: Supported in Edge 17 release
    • Firefox: Already well supported
  • CMS limitations
    • E-commerce CMS's (SFCC, Magento) have a lot of pre-built functionality and can be less configurable
    • Content CMS's (Sitecore/Umbraco) are more promising

heading: Examples
content:
• Twitter
  • Google Maps
  • Forbes
  • Lancôme
  • Alibaba

content:
• PWA Directory
  • Any search engine
  • Windows App Store (Project Westminster)
  • App Store / Google Play Store…someday?

heading: Let's Revisit Steve and His Little Phone
iPhone Apps Timeline
content:
2007: iPhone introduced, third-party apps must be web apps

2008: App Store launched, native apps take over the world

...Native Apps...

...Native Apps...

...Native Apps...

2018: iOS begins to support PWAs
